habitat_description: Endemic to one relatively small cave system: General Davis Cave, Greenbrier County, southeastern West Virginia (Petranka 1998), this species was previously regarded as an extreme variant of G. porphyriticus by Blaney and Blaney (1978). Limited biochemical information suggests that subterraneus differs from porphyriticus populations (Howard et al. 1984), but further study is warranted. Petranka (1998), Crother et al. (2000), and Collins and Taggart (2002) all treat this as a distinct species. A subterranean obligate, G. subterraneus is limited to limestone-cave stream passages with large amounts of decaying organic matter and occurs in streams and on mud banks margins. Undoubtedly dependent on water quality and availability of organic material flushed into cave from outside (Beachy 2005).
